Introduction

Intimate partner violence (IPV) is a highly prevalent and complex public health issue.  It encompasses both actions and threats of abuseâ€”physical, sexual, psychologic, or economicâ€”perpetrated by a current or former partner or spouse.Despite its high prevalence, IPV is underreported.  Victims may have multiple reasons for avoiding disclosure, including perceived stigma, safety concerns/fear of retribution, and shame or self-blame.  In addition, IPV is often undiagnosed because external signs of abuse can be subtle or absent.  Therefore, addressing IPV first requires identifying affected patients through routine screening.

Epidemiology and risk factors



IPV is highly prevalent, with an estimated lifetime risk of 1 in 3 for women and 1 in 4 for men.  It affects patients across all demographic groups, regardless of age, gender, sexual orientation, race, or socioeconomic status.



The most common types of IPV include:



  • Psychological abuse, in which the perpetrator uses threats of action (eg, words, gestures) to cause emotional or psychological trauma to the victim (eg, limiting finances, stalking, social isolation).
  • Sexual abuse, which involves the use of physical force or intimidation to compel a victim to engage in a sexual act against their will (regardless of whether or not the act is completed).
  • Physical abuse, in which the perpetrator uses physical force to cause harm, injury, or death. In many cases, IPV starts with psychological/emotional abuse that then escalates to physical abuse.


The victims at highest risk are women of child-bearing age.  Other risk factors include a history of IPV, young age (age <24), and having witnessed or experienced violence as a child.  The incidence of IPV also increases during times of stress or social change (eg, marriage, move/relocation, job loss).  Pregnancy and postpartum are especially high-risk periods due to the presence of physical (eg, sleep deprivation), interpersonal, and/or financial stressors.



Presenting signs and symptoms that increase suspicion for IPV (

) include:



  • Frequent health care visits with different providers or at the emergency department
  • Repeated injuries or sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
  • Unexplained injuries or injuries in certain locations (eg, head, neck, abdomen, genitals)
  • Nonspecific somatic symptoms (eg, headaches, back pain, chronic pelvic pain)
  • Resistance to being evaluated alone (eg, partner insistent on being present)
  • Signs of fear or psychologic distress
  • Suspicious examination findings (eg, bruises in various stages of healing)


However, many patients experiencing IPV have no identifiable risk factors or overt signs or symptoms of abuse.  Victims may, in fact, actively attempt to conceal signs of abuse.  For these reasons, the most effective method for identifying IPV is routine screening.

Evaluation



Routine screening can identify affected patients, facilitate early intervention, and potentially prevent further harm. Screening guidelines include:



  • Who to screen:  all patients but particularly women of reproductive age
  • When to screen:  most instances of patient contact with health care services but at least annually during the routine health care maintenance examination
  • Where to screen:  most health care settings, provided the patient feels safe and comfortable. However, screening is particularly indicated in the following settings:
    • Prenatal and postpartum visits (pregnant women are at higher risk for injury, homicide, and obstetric complications [eg, preterm labor, placental abruption] caused by abdominal trauma)
    • Visits for reproductive health (eg, STIs, pelvic pain)
    • When suspicious signs or symptoms are present
  • How to screen
    • Ensure a safe, supportive, private setting (ie, no partner) and assure confidentiality.
    • Approach patient interaction with a sensitive, nonjudgmental demeanor.
    • Integrate screening for IPV into routine history-taking to help normalize the experience. Many settings use a standardized questionnaire as part of their intake forms.
    • When the suspicion for IPV is high, employ strategies to introduce the topic of IPV without causing offense or provoking defensiveness:
      • Begin with a normalizing statement (eg, "I sometimes see patients with similar symptoms caused by not feeling safe") or with indirect and open-ended questions (eg, "How are things going at home?").
      • Transition to general questions (eg, "How safe do you feel in your relationship?").
      • Finally, ask specific questions (eg, "Have you ever been hit by your partner?").


Importantly, patients should not be pressured to disclose IPV due to the risk of alienating the patient and deterring future attempts to seek help.

Management



Patients who self-disclose or screen positive for IPV first require prompt evaluation for imminent danger. After assessing for immediate safety, other priorities include:



  • Identifying risks for escalating violence (eg, increase in controlling behavior, access to firearms, increased alcohol use, recent attempts by the patient to leave or seek help)
  • Developing a personalized safety plan for emergencies, including housing and a kit for essentials (eg, birth certificate, medications)
  • Connecting the patient to additional resources (eg, counseling, shelters, legal aid, support groups)


Providers should avoid pressuring the patient to report the abuse to legal authorities or to directly confront/leave the perpetrator.  This approach can undermine patient trust, disrespect patient autonomy, and prevent future attempts to seek help.  Worse, they may provoke the perpetrator to retaliate.

Prognosis and complications



Patient outcomes are highly variable.  However, increasing severity of abuse directly correlates with worsening health outcomes for the victim; in addition, abuse increases over time, and the cumulative effects of abuse can persist for years after the abuse has ended.



Victims can experience severe physical injury and even homicide: ~10% of homicides worldwide are associated with IPV.  Victims of IPV also experience long-term consequences, including mental health disorders (eg, posttraumatic stress disorder), substance use disorders, unintended pregnancy and/or obstetric complications, and overall diminished quality of life.  Furthermore, children exposed to IPV are at risk for developmental challenges and experiencing IPV in the future through the perpetuation of intergenerational cycles of violence.

Prevention



IPV affects individuals but also represents a serious public health concern for the broader community.  Prevention strategies include raising awareness, advocating for policy reforms, and addressing systemic factors for social injustice (eg, poverty).  Collaboration between various stakeholders is typically needed.

Summary



Intimate partner violence (IPV) (

Patients experiencing active IPV require prompt safety assessment, help creating a personalized safety plan, and referral to additional support and intervention resources.
